title: Help. What do I do?
question: I was at fault to a accident in 2016. I just got notice about the large amount of money the other party is trying to recover. This exhaust my insurance money to be paid out. He is seeking around $30,000 more dollars from medical Bill's, ambulance bill, ect. The accident was minor. He was on a motorcycle and I tapped him while we were both at a red light. He went up in the air a little, and landed on his right arm/shoulder. I read all the paperwork and it says that he was involved in 2 other motorcycle accidents prior to this one. If I had bumped a car there would have been minor damage, if any damage at all. The other party and his private doctor say that he has trouble gripping things with his right hand, due to his injured elbow, back and neck, and that he has suffered emotional/physical pain. I feel he is just looking for a hand out, because he did not fall that hard at all. He is a 53 year old Male. I believe he is going to sue me with the next step. What should I do??
answers: You should accept responsibility for the harm you caused.
Redirecting to the car accident section of this service

You should keep your opinions about somebody else's injuries to yourself because you have no idea what you are talking about and no qualifications that justify making opinions on very limited information. You didn't hit a car, so speculation about what damage a car would have sustained is irrelevant.

At least you have insurance. It will advance all appropriate defenses on your behalf and pay any sums that you are legally obligated to pay, up to policy limits. It has an obligation to try to resolve your claims within policy limits. Ask it to do so, in writing and ask to be informed of all settlement offers it receives and makes, as well as its evaluation of your exposure to damages. If a judgment is obtained against you in excess of your policy limits, you may wish to consult with bankruptcy counsel.
Don’t worry, let your insurance take care of it. If you have more questions, contact any of us

If you get sued let your insurance company handle it. Tell them about the lawsuit immediately, though I’m sure the guys attorney will send your adjuster a copy anyway. Then call your insurance agent and up your policy limits to a reasonable amount so you next time you don’t undergo all this stress trying to save a few bucks a month on insurance.

More information is needed to evaluate this situation. You need to consult in person with an experienced and seasoned Bankruptcy lawyer in your area. A local Bankruptcy attorney will be more familiar with the lay of the land and tendencies of local Courts and Judges. An experienced local Bankruptcy attorney can evaluate what evidence, statements or identifications are likely to be admitted at a Creditor/Debtor hearing or Bankruptcy Trial. They can also provide an assessment of the consequences and potential fines or sentencing guidelines the crime involved.

The Clerk at the Bankruptcy Court may be able to provide you with some explanations and procedural information, but not legal advice specific to your Bankruptcy Case. Your local Legal Aid office may assist you for free on a sliding fee scale, depending on you income of assets. Legal Aid offices are staffed with individuals to assist the public with legal questions and the selection, completion and filing of applicable legal documents. These individuals are knowledgeable in criminal law issues. While they won’t always give you legal advice specific to your case, they will give you practical advice on how best to proceed, what forms to file, and anticipated time frames and debt relief guidelines involved.

This is not legal advice! You need to speak to a Bankruptcy attorney who is licensed in your state for legal advice. I strongly recommend you make an appointment with a competent and experienced Bankruptcy attorney in your area, who can take time to carefully evaluate and explain all options available. This is merely suggestions for you to think about in discussing your situation with the local attorney.
